facts.text: Removal of Difficulties Order made by Central Government on December 2, 1950 under s.12 Finance Act 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The Removal of Difficulties Order was made by the Central Government on December 2, 1950, in exercise of the powers conferred by s. 12 of the Finance Act, 1950, and Section 5 of the Opium

facts.text: Paragraph 2 of Removal of Difficulties Order requires taking into account depreciation under Part B State laws or any law relating to tax on profits of business in computing written down value under s.10(5)(b).

anchor.surface_text: Paragraph 2 runs thus - In making any assessment under the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, all depreciation actually allowed under any laws or rules of a Part B State relating to income-tax

issues.text: Whether paragraph 2 of the Removal of Difficulties Order applies only when a difficulty is actually experienced in giving effect to the Indian Income-tax Act in a particular case?

anchor.surface_text: He contends however that it is only when a difficulty is actually experienced in giving effect to the Indian Income-tax Act that the provision of the Order can come into operation in a particular case. In the cases now under consideration, he argues, no such difficulty was actually experienced and so, paragraph 2 would have no application.

issues.text: Whether the omission of the words 'of a Part B State' in the second part of paragraph 2 of the Removal of Difficulties Order ('or any law relating to tax on profits of business') is by way of ellipsis?

anchor.surface_text: According to Mr. Kolah these words of a Part B State were intended to be read also after the words any law in the latter portion and were omitted by way of ellipsis so that the sentence might not appear cumbersome. holdings.text: we are of opinion that the High Court was right in answering the question referred in these cases out of which Civil Appeals Nos. 599 and 601 have arisen, in the affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: we are of opinion that the High Court was right in answering the question referred in these cases out of which Civil Appeals Nos. 599 and 601 have arisen, in the affirmative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Words 'which would have been allowed' mean what should have been allowed if proper claim made; implicit in language; legislative intention credits authority with knowledge that claim ordinarily made.

holdings.text: The High Court has answered the second question in the affirmative and the correctness of that is no longer in dispute before us.
holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court held notification ultra vires; not disputed before Supreme Court.

holdings.text: the High Court held that the provisions of this paragraph applied to these two cases of assessment for 1951-52 and under them the depreciation already availed of by the assessees under the Bhavnagar War Profits Act had to be deducted in computing the written down value. The correctness of this decision is challenged before us in C.A. Nos. 600 and 602 of 1962.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Paragraph 2 requires deduction of depreciation under prior laws including Bhavnagar War Profits Act as 'any law relating to tax on profits of business'.

holdings.text: In our opinion, the High Court rightly rejected this contention. The consequence of the Removal of Difficulties Order being validly made under s. 12 of the Finance Act, 1950, is that paragraph 2 of the Order (as also the other paragraphs) have to be applied and no exception can be made.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court rightly rejected this contention. The consequence of the Removal of Difficulties Order being validly made under s. 12 of the Finance Act, 1950, is that paragraph 2 of the Order (as also the other paragraphs) have to be applied and no exception can be made.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Once validly made on government's satisfaction of difficulties, order applies generally to all assessments without needing case-specific difficulty; per precedent Dewan Bahadur Ram Gopal Mills.

holdings.text: After careful consideration we have however come to the conclusion that the omission of the words of a Part B State in this paragraph is not by way of ellipsis but a deliberate omission with the intention of including laws which could not be stated to be laws of a Part B State but had been laws in the same area at a time before they formed part of a Part B State.

anchor.surface_text: After careful consideration we have however come to the conclusion that the omission of the words of a Part B State in this paragraph is not by way of ellipsis but a deliberate omission with the intention of including laws which could not be stated to be laws of a Part B State but had been laws in the same area at a time before they formed part of a Part B State.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deliberate to broaden scope to prior component state laws; if ellipsis, further words would be omitted; contrast with Merged States Order; purposive to include profits tax laws.

holdings.text: We have come to the conclusion that the Bhavnagar War Profits Act is within the words any law relating to tax on profits of business in paragraph 2 of the Removal of Difficulties Order.

anchor.surface_text: We have come to the conclusion that the Bhavnagar War Profits Act is within the words any law relating to tax on profits of business in paragraph 2 of the Removal of Difficulties Order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fits second limb; deliberate omission of qualifier; intended to cover pre-Part B laws on business profits tax.

holdings.text: We hold that the High Court has rightly decided that the depreciation availed of by the assessee under the Bhavnagar War Profits Act was a deductible amount in computing the written down value of the assets.

anchor.surface_text: We hold that the High Court has rightly decided that the depreciation availed of by the assessee under the Bhavnagar War Profits Act was a deductible amount in computing the written down value

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative: para 2 applies, covers Bhavnagar Act, deduction required.

holdings.text: All the appeals are therefore dismissed with costs.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Kamala Mills Ltd.  1949 17 I.T.R. 130.

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Kamala Mills Ltd.  1949 17 I.T.R. 130.  the Calcutta High Court decided that the words actually allowed in s. 10 5  b  of the Indian Income-tax Act as amended by the Income-tax  Amendment  Act  XXIII of 1941  are unambiguous and connote the idea that the allowance was in fact given effect to.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Kamala Mills Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: the words actually allowed in s. 10 5  b  of the Indian Income-tax Act as amended by the Income-tax Amendment Act XXIII of 1941 are unambiguous and connote the idea that the allowance was in fact given effect to. The Court rejected a contention of the Income-tax authorities that the expression actually allowed means allowable under the law in force

precedents.citation: Rajaratna Naranbhai Mills Ltd., v. Commissioner of Income-tax  1950 18 I.T.R. 122.

anchor.surface_text: Rajaratna Naranbhai Mills Ltd., v. Commissioner of Income-tax  1950 18 I.T.R. 122.  the Bombay High Court had to construe the words the amount of depreciation applicable and held that as the words were not depreciation allowed but depreciation applicable it was immaterial whether the assessee got any benefit of depreciation in any previous year.

precedents.case_name: Rajaratna Naranbhai Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: the words the amount of depreciation applicable meant it was immaterial whether the assessee got any benefit of depreciation in any previous year as the words were not depreciation allowed but depreciation applicable

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax Hyderabad v. Dewan Bahadur Ram Gopal Mills Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax Hyderabad v. Dewan Bahadur Ram Gopal Mills Ltd. , this Court held that it was for the Central Government to determine if any difficulty of the nature indicated in s. 12 had arisen and then to make such order or give such direction as appeared to it to be necessary to remove the difficulty.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax Hyderabad v. Dewan Bahadur Ram Gopal Mills Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: it was for the Central Government to determine if any difficulty of the nature indicated in s. 12 had arisen and then to make such order or give such direction as appeared to it to be necessary to remove the difficulty

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court rightly rejected this contention. The consequence of the Removal of Difficulties Order being validly made under s. 12 of the Finance Act, 1950, is that paragraph 2 of the Order (as also the other paragraphs) have to be applied and no exception can be made.

anchor.surface_text: After careful consideration we have however come to the conclusion that the omission of the words of a Part B State in this paragraph is not by way of ellipsis but a deliberate omission with the intention of including laws which could not be stated to be laws of a Part B State but had been laws in the same area at a time before they formed part of a Part B State.
